revisions.rev:
{{NCAATeamSeason |Mode=Basketball |Year=2003â04 |Prev year=2002â03 |Next year=2004â05 |Team=Providence Friars |Image=Providence Friars P script logo.gif |Conference=Big East Conference |Division= |ShortConference=Big East |CoachRank= |APRank=21 |Record=20–9 |ConfRecord=11–5 |HeadCoach=[[Tim Welsh]] |AsstCoach1=Steve DeMeo |AsstCoach2=Phil Seymore |AsstCoach3=Bob Walsh |MVP=[[Ryan Gomes]] |Captain=Ryan Gomes |StadiumArena=[[Dunkin' Donuts Center]] |Champion= |BowlTourney=[[2004 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA]] |BowlTourneyResult=#5, Midwest Region, First Round }} The '''2003â04 Providence Friars men's basketball team''' represented [[Providence College]] in the [[2008â09 Big East Conference men's basketball season|Big East Conference]]. The team finished with a 11â5 conference record and a 20â9 record overall. Coming off an 18â14 record and a second-round [[2003 National Invitation Tournament|NIT]] loss in 2002â03, the team returned all five starters for coach [[Tim Welsh]]'s sixth season with the Friars. However, forward Romuald Augustin transferred to [[Bryant Bulldogs men's basketball|Bryant College]] for his fifth year of eligibility,{{cite web|url=http://www.thecowl.com/2.7829/mills-transfers-to-university-of-omaha-nebraska-1.1103724|title=Mills transfers to University of Omaha-Nebraska|work=The Cowl|first=Kevin|last=O'Brien|date=2004-09-23|accessdate=2010-02-07}} while [[walk-on (sports)|walk-on]] guard Chris Burns also transferred to Bryant for his sophomore season.{{cite web|url=http://www.bryantbulldogs.com/sports/mbkb/2004/news/2004Dec30BloomTwo|title=Burns Makes Good On Comeback (Post Tourney Notes)|work=[[Bryant University|Bryant College]]|date=2004-12-30|accessdate=2010-02-07}} The team also lost two departing seniors, guard Kareem Hayletts and forward Stephen Traugott. On February 24, after playing in 12 games for the Friars, senior forward [[MÄris Ä»aksa]] left the team to play professional basketball in [[Slovenia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.friars.com/sports/m-baskbl/spec-rel/022404aaa.html|title=Maris Laksa Leaves Providence Men's Basketball Team To Pursue Professional Career|work=Friars.com|date=2004-02-24|accessdate=2010-02-07}} The Friars began the season receiving votes in both polls, but not ranked in either. Following an 8â1 start that included a win over #14 [[Illinois Fighting Illini men's basketball|Illinois]], the Friars earned a #25 ranking in the [[AP Poll]] in time for their January 5 matchup with #18 [[Texas Longhorns men's basketball|Texas]]. The Friars took the Longhorns to overtime, but as time expired in the overtime period, Texas forward [[P. J. Tucker]] released a layup to give the Longhorns a two-point win. The controversial shot was reviewed for more than five minutes by the officials, who determined that the clock read "0.00" but the red backboard light had not yet gone off when the ball was released, which at the time overruled the clock.{{cite web|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/ncb/recap?gameId=240052507|title=Officials have to check replay on shot|work=[[Associated Press]]|publisher=[[ESPN.com]]|date=2004-01-05|accessdate=2010-02-07}} Despite the close loss, the Friars re-emerged in the top 25 three weeks later, following a road win over #4 [[Connecticut Huskies men's basketball|Connecticut]]. A six-game winning streak that began with a win over #18 [[Syracuse Orange men's basketball|Syracuse]] propelled the Friars to a #12 ranking in the AP Poll on March 1. This was followed by two home losses to close out the regular season, and a #3 seed in the [[2004 Big East Men's Basketball Tournament]]. Following a first-round bye, the Friars dropped a three-point game to [[Villanova Wildcats men's basketball|Villanova]] in the quarterfinals, leading to a #5 seed in the [[2004 NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Tournament|NCAA Tournament]]. In the first round, the Friars were defeated 66â58 by the #12 seed, [[Pacific Tigers men's basketball|Pacific]]. The Friars ended the season with a #21 ranking in the AP Poll. The Friars were led in scoring (18.9 ppg) and rebounding (9.4 rpg) by junior forward [[Ryan Gomes]]. He became the fourth Friar to be named a [[2004 NCAA Men's Basketball All-Americans|First Team All-American]] by the [[Associated Press]]. ==Roster== {{CBB roster/Header|year=2003|team=Providence Friars|hdr_bgcolor=black|subhdr_bgcolor=#C0C0C0|hdr_txtcolor=white|subhdr_txtcolor=black|high_school=y}} {{CBB roster/Player|first=Donnie|last=McGrath|num=1|pos=G|ft=6|in=4|lbs=190|class=So|home=[[Katonah, New York]]|high_school=[[John F.
